Problem:
Consider a control system governed by the matrix differential equation \(\dot{x} = Mx + u\), where \(M\) is a constant matrix and \(u\) is a control input. We examine the influence of applying a transformation \( h(x) = e^{Nt}x \), with \(N\) being another constant matrix, on the system’s trajectory.

If \( h(x) \) is applied to an initial vector \( x_0 \) at \( t = 0 \), and then \( x \) evolves under \(\dot{x} = Mx\) without any control intervention (\(u = 0\)), will \( x(t) \) at \( t = T \) be the same as if \( x_0 \) was simply allowed to evolve under \(\dot{x} = Mx\)?
Explanation: Applying \( h(x) \) changes the initial state \( x_0 \) to \( e^{N0}x_0 = x_0 \). However, since the transformation is time-dependent, \( x(t) = e^{Nt}x(t) \) is not generally the same as \( e^{Mt}x_0 \). The eigenspaces influenced by \( N \) could modify the trajectory differently than those only influenced by \( M \).
